block.p: * American Southwest Mortgage Investments Corp., Tucson, Ariz., a mortgage finance investment company, acquired most of the assets of Residential Mortgage Investments Inc., Fort Worth, for $1.1 million in cash and about 1.8 million new American shares. * Angeion Corp., Plymouth, Minn., a maker of medical components, received approval from the Japanese Government to begin marketing two additional lines of accessory devices.

* American Southwest Mortgage Investments Corp., Tucson, Ariz., a mortgage finance investment company, acquired most of the assets of Residential Mortgage Investments Inc., Fort Worth, for $1.1 million in cash and about 1.8 million new American shares. * Angeion Corp., Plymouth, Minn., a maker of medical components, received approval from the Japanese Government to begin marketing two additional lines of accessory devices.

* BTR P.L.C., London, a conglomerate, raised its hostile offer for Hawker Siddeley Group P.L.C. by about 3 percent, to $2.76 billion. Hawker Siddeley, an industrial group, rejected the sweetened offer as a "token increase." * CalFed Inc., Los Angeles, a financial services holding company, will sell its institutional investment management company, TSA Capital Management, to Mitchum, Jones & Templeton Inc., Los Angeles, an investment banking and management firm, and a group of TSA executives. Terms were not disclosed. * Dow Corning Corp., Midland, Mich., a joint venture of Dow Chemical Co. and Corning Inc., plans a four-year, $262 million expansion of its manufacturing plants in Barry, Wales. * General Motors Corp., Detroit, started vehicle assembly at its joint venture operation in Tunisia. * Hanson P.L.C., London, said the Federal Trade Commission had requested additional information on its $625 million proposed merger with Beazer P.L.C. * Mobil Corp., New York, has made two more discoveries off Nigeria, of an estimated 450 million barrels of recoverable oil. Mobil has a 40 percent interest in the discoveries. The remaining 60 percent is held by Nigerian National Petroleum Corp. * Union Carbide Corp., Danbury, Conn., said it had developed a technology, called Cansolv, to removes up to 99 percent of sulfur dioxide, which causes acid rain, from industrial and utility plant emissions. * Zenith Electronics Corp., Glenview, Ill., and American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said their all-digital high-definition television system was certified for testing by the Federal Communications Commission.
